unnormalised: In a shocking turn of events, the Delhi High Court today adjourned the hearing in the infamous "Gurgaon Highway Robbery" case until 10/11/2024. The adjournment came after Adv. Sharma, representing the accused, requested more time to present new evidence. Apparently, this evidence could potentially exonerate his client.
normalised: In a shocking turn of events, the Delhi High Court today adjourned the hearing in the infamous "Gurgaon Highway Robbery" case until tenth November two thousand and twenty four. The adjournment came after Advocate Sharma, representing the accused, requested more time to present new evidence. Apparently, this evidence could potentially exonerate his client.

unnormalised: The case, which dates back to 15/08/2023, involves allegations that Rakesh Kumar and his accomplices robbed a truck carrying electronics worth Rs. 50 lakh. Kumar is charged under IPC Section 392 (robbery) and Section 397 (robbery with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt). If convicted, he faces a possible jail term of up to 10 years.
normalised: The case, which dates back to fifteenth August two thousand and twenty three, involves allegations that Rakesh Kumar and his accomplices robbed a truck carrying electronics worth rupee fifty lakh. Kumar is charged under I-P-C Section three hundred and ninety two (robbery) and Section three hundred and ninety seven (robbery with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt). If convicted, he faces a possible jail term of up to ten years.

unnormalised: According to sources, the new evidence presented by Adv. Sharma includes CCTV footage from a nearby petrol pump and witness statements that allegedly contradict the prosecution's claims. The prosecution, led by Sr. Public Prosecutor Mrs. Mehra, has dismissed the evidence as "fabricated" and "misleading."
normalised: According to sources, the new evidence presented by Advocate Sharma includes C-C-T-V footage from a nearby petrol pump and witness statements that allegedly contradict the prosecution's claims. The prosecution, led by Senior Public Prosecutor Missus Mehra, has dismissed the evidence as "fabricated" and "misleading."

unnormalised: The delay has understandably frustrated the victim, Mr. Gupta, owner of "Gupta Electronics." He expressed his disappointment, stating that he hopes justice will be served soon. "It's been too long," he lamented. "I lost everything that day; now my family is suffering."
normalised: The delay has understandably frustrated the victim, Mister Gupta, owner of "Gupta Electronics." He expressed his disappointment, stating that he hopes justice will be served soon. "It's been too long," he lamented. "I lost everything that day; now my family is suffering."

unnormalised: The case continues to draw significant media attention. Legal experts suggest that the new evidence could significantly impact the outcome. Whether Rakesh Kumar will be found guilty or innocent remains to be seen, but one thing is sure, the coming weeks will be a roller-coaster ride.
normalised: The case continues to draw significant media attention. Legal experts suggest that the new evidence could significantly impact the outcome. Whether Rakesh Kumar will be found guilty or innocent remains to be seen, but one thing is sure, the coming weeks will be a roller-coaster ride.
